div.p: S. Your letters were most welcome to me, my most distinguished Bullinger.

From them, no less than from all others, I clearly understand your desire not only to increase our friendship but also to extend it for all time; to achieve this, I will exert every effort as much as I can. The only thing that weighs on me is that I am not given the means to somehow repay your kindnesses. For you have honored me so often with your most welcome writings, and I have nothing to write except my desire and effort to deserve well of you, yet I will strive to appear grateful to you someday.

What you write about Swiss (Helvetian) concord is sweeter to me than Hylaean honey; for I know how much the enemies of Germany, and indeed the pseudo-Germans themselves, promise themselves profit from your discord. I say the same about the friendship of the Genevans, which may the Lord confirm.

That boastful Bolviler (likely a reference to a person causing trouble) is worthy of this description: there are many such troublemakers. I have long known the mind of our Philip; it can hardly be said how unjustly he is treated by those to whom he has rendered many benefits; he has certainly nourished many whelps until now. The Duke of Bavaria was holding a diet (assembly) at Landshut, which was to be undertaken very unfortunately.
Our Faber wanted to play the role of Parasceve (a preparatory day, often referring to Friday). The nobles are eagerly seeking the gospel with the most ardent prayers.

The electors will meet in Ulm; King Ferdinand will also come to them immediately after the Christmas holidays. There are many things to write to you; but it was not possible, I will write soon about what is to be hoped from these assemblies. Farewell, my Bullinger, and love your Gereon.
My son is performing his duties well; he will feel my kindness towards him more every day. In Augsburg, most swiftly, November 26, in the year etc. 57.
To the most distinguished and learned man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, my most esteemed lord and brother.
